Deftux
Feature Stub

Recent:

What it is: When you select a word on a Kindle, it defines it either with its internal dictionary, with X-Ray, which is contextual to the book, or with Wikipedia.

Why it’s good: The main complaint that I hear about Kindles is that they aren’t books. Kindles aren’t books. The change in form makes them entirely different from books, and we use them in different ways. Amazon clearly wants to make the Kindle as good as it can be (even if not bookish) and this lookup feature is a brilliant example of the sort of things that books cannot accomplish.

Highlighting a single word causes the Kindle to automatically look it up. You’ll see in this case that it first selects the “X-Ray” tab in the modal window. X-Ray is a feature in texts that you buy from Amazon in which it catalogs larger ideas and links them to multiple spots in the text. In this case, the Kindle notices that the word that I selected is defined in X-Ray, so it shows it to me first. Since the X-Ray result is more contextually relevant, it is most likely to be what I’m looking for.

The dictionaries themselves are useful, but when you are connected to the internet you also have the ability to pull up a relevant Wikipedia article. This is incredibly useful when reading historical works or other texts with proper nouns that are unlikely to be found in a dictionary.

Instead of just making a device that tries to mimic a book as much as possible, Amazon extends the functionality of the text. Reading on a Kindle is reading hypertext that hasn’t experienced the tyranny of graphic design; it retains much of the functionality without being concerned about colors, layout, or being flashy.

What it is: When you wiggle your mouse quickly in OSX’s most recent update, the mouse pointer briefly becomes larger.

Why it’s good: Besides being incredibly helpful when you’re in a multiscreen environment, (Especially when you are hooked up to a projector) the reason that this particular design is so effective is that it mimics the current user behavior. When you can’t find your mouse pointer, you shake it around because eyes are better adapted to noticing motion.

The decision here works because the user didn’t have to learn and remember a new behavior. Instead, the designers at Apple paid attention to the current behavior and took another step towards bridging the gap between the software and the user.

What it is: This is a feature you’re familiar with, when you stick a limb (or item) in between the doors of an elevator, the doors re-open.

Why it’s good: Ostensibly, the reason that this feature exists is for safety—and I enjoy not having to worry about being maimed in the mornings. In practice, though, it’s used as a hack to hold an elevator.

You can get incredible information through watching how people hack systems. In this case, when users need to hold an elevator door open, sticking an arm through the doors is much easier than finding a specific button. It’s reliable and easy, but it’s also a behavior that we learn from watching others.

The real reason that this is interesting, though, is that what the designers made as a safety feature has become a standard use. It’s a testament to how robust the feature is: we potentially disregard our bodily integrity for convenience because we know it will work.

Robust features (especially safety features) have this effect. You can see it in things like autosave functions. When you work with a product that has a robust autosave with historical capabilities (like Google Docs), it fundamentally changes how you interact with a filesystem. Whenever we produce something that is this robust and reliable, we open up entirely new possibilities for our users.

What it is: When you search for an item in OSX’s System Preferences, it gives you suggestions and highlights the relevant categories. When you select an item, it flashes the category before opening it.

Why it’s good: For search-heavy users, having a helpful suggestive search is enough. As someone who uses search a lot, I hammer in a term and hit a suggestion as my first attempt at finding something. These plain-language suggestions highlight the categories as I mouse over them, which helps me understand the difference between similarly-named terms.

The reason that this is so effective is that it uses the search to teach browsing users where things are. If you are a user who prefers browsing, after a period of not finding what you are looking for, you use the search field. Now the interface shows you where you can find it next time. It orients you to the categorization so that you can use your preferred method in the future.

What it is: Spotify upgrades itself in the background, but it needs a restart in order to apply it. The way they tell you about it is a little banner that says “Hello. We’ve got a new version of Spotify ready for you. Restart now to make it yours.”

Why it’s good: I don’t think I need to do much consensus building for us all to agree that updates are annoying. Developers have gotten better at making updates less painful for users by moving them to the background (Like Chrome, or iOS and Android auto updates) but it still breaks down sometimes and requires something from the user, like a restart or an acceptance of new permissions.

Spotify provokes a sense of ownership in how they tell you about this change. Instead of shaming you (Like Chrome does) or blocking you from using it, (I’m looking at you, Blizzard) Spotify makes me feel like this is something that I would want to do.

While it would be better to tell me what new benefits this upgrade brings, there are only so many times that I want to read “Fixes random bugs in 1% of our userbase.”
